meta.title: COVID-19 Update - Lisle CUSD 202

body.class: fsLiveMode fsHasHeader fsHasMenu fsHasFooter fsHasOneColumnLayout fsSection1268 fsHasTheme2

div.p:
5801 Westview Ln.
Lisle, IL 60532
Attendance Line: 630.493.8199

5207 Center Ave.

Attendance Line: 630.493.8299

1800 Short St.
Lisle, IL 60532
Attendance Line: 630.493.8399

p.meta: We know there are continuing questions and concerns about COVID-19 Coronavirus and its impact on our schools and community. Resources and information related to the rapidly evolving situation are available below. We will update our information as necessary.

div.class: fsElement fsPostElement fsList fsThumbnailOriginal fsThumbnailSmall fsItemCount_5

div.p: Dear Lisle 202 Learning Community,

This afternoon, Governor Pritzker extended school closure order through the end of the 2019-2020 school year. Based on this new information, school buildings will not re-open and students will continue to engage in Remote Learning for the remainder of the school year. Here’s what Lisle 202 is doing to help plan for the continuation of Remote Learning.

The information from the first Remote Learning Feedback Survey was extremely helpful to our staff as we planned extended Remote Learning opportunities. Please consider sharing your input on this survey to help us continue to effectively support our learning community.

Our schools will continue to develop Remote Learning opportunities for the remainder of the school year. Remote Learning information is posted on our Remote Learning page of our website and additional detailed information will be shared from the schools as it is available.
Meals are available for pick up for all children under the age of 18, or still enrolled in school.
Food Service will also continue according to the following schedule:

li.p: Days/Dates: Mondays & Wednesday through the remainder of the school year
Where: Lisle Senior High School, 1800 Short Street, Lisle, IL

div.p: If your family is in need of additional food support, please visit the following resources for assistance.

We have received questions about how to help others during these unique times. Our local Lisle Township Food Pantry is available to support additional food needs for the families in our community. This organization is currently in need of assistance as well to continue to support those in need. Did you know that the Food Pantry can purchase $8 worth of food for every dollar spent at the Northern Illinois Food Bank? Every dollar donated makes a huge difference for this organization and for our community. For more information, please visit www.lisletownship.com/blog/2020/04/08/support-lisle-township-food-pantry/

We are committed to sharing information with you as it becomes available. We will use our mass communications system to send messages via email, text, phone, and post on social media. Information will also be updated on our website on the COVID-19 page. If you need assistance, please email info@lisle202.org or call 630.493.8000.

Thank you for your patience as we plan the next steps for our students and families. Please know we are planning learning opportunities to best support our students in these unique circumstances. Thank you for your continued support.
Thank you,

Keith Filipiak
Superintendent

p.b: Additional Health and Wellness Support Resources:

hr.p: The Illinois Department of Human Services’ Mental Health Division has launched Call4Calm, a free emotional support text line for Illinois residents experiencing stress and mental health issues related to COVID-19.

Individuals who would like to speak with a mental health professional can text “TALK” to 5-5-2-0-2-0, or for Spanish, “HABLAR” to the same number: 5-5-2-0-2-0. Individuals can also text with key words such as “unemployment” or “food” or “shelter” and will receive information on how navigate and access supports and services.

Women, Infant, Children (WIC) is here to help. The WIC Program provides nutrition education, breastfeeding support, and community referrals and vouchers for nutritious supplemental foods at no-cost to eligible pregnant, postpartum, or breastfeeding women, infants and children living in DuPage County.
Currently, you can enroll in WIC without going to a clinic. WIC families have an option to do phone-based WIC appointments, and complete online nutrition education.
Call DuPage County Health Department for enrollment information at (630) 682-7400.

Northern Illinois Food Bank partners with 900 feeding programs across 13 counties to serve our neighbors needing food. If you or someone you know is in need of food please use the locator map to find a food pantry or soup kitchen near you. Use the contact information provided to confirm hours of distribution and residency requirements.

The Food Bank’s SNAP Outreach Team is also fielding calls and online requests 7 days per week related to SNAP (food stamps) applications and locating a pantry. Some of the SNAP eligibility requirements have been temporarily lifted due to COVID-19. For assistance call 844-600-7627 or use the online contact form.
Visit the Food Bank website to learn more about how to give help and get help (https://solvehungertoday.org/coronavirus/
Please visit our website for a list of additional support resources being offered for a variety of needs.

span.span: It's hard to believe we are almost a month into Remote Learning for our school district. We are extremely proud of how well the students adapted to this new learning environment and understand there is a myriad of emotions associated with trying to find balance in this new “norm”. Juggling your family’s health and safety, professional obligations, along with your student’s school assignments can be a challenge, but please know we truly appreciate your partnership in continuing your student’s education under these unique circumstances.

Remote Learning is currently scheduled to continue through April 30 and our staff will continue to support your child’s academic growth throughout this time. As your student engages in his/her learning at home, we encourage you to focus on how your child can get the most out of the time he/she spends on academics rather than on getting “all” or “much” of the work done. Just as in normal days, some days will be more productive than others, and that is ok. If ever it feels like “too much”, please take a break and come back to the task when you and your child feel ready and refreshed.

Earlier this week we noted there are many end-of-year milestone events that unfortunately will be cancelled or postponed. This is certainly not how we envisioned the end of year for seniors, eighth graders, fifth graders, and every grade in between. No one understands and empathizes with your disappointment more than our teachers and staff across the school district. Please be assured that our schools are working on options to celebrate the end of year to the extent that it will be possible.

I know we’ve said thank you a lot lately, but we are incredibly grateful for your support, understanding, flexibility, and partnership, especially during challenging times like these. Please enjoy the weekend and we’ll see you and your child back online next week!

div.p: Dear Lisle 202 Community,

Thank you for your support and patience as we embark on a new chapter of Illinois’ Remote Learning Days, which are in effect through April 30. The Illinois State Board of Education (ISBE) provided guidance for what is expected as we move forward. The District and individual school Remote Learning Plans can be found on our website. The following summarizes our plan for the coming weeks:

ul.li: Starting on Tuesday, April 7, all grade levels will participate in remote learning. Teachers will contact students on Tuesday with information on what to expect and their availability to answer questions and support students.

Students are expected to engage in continuing the educational experience during Remote Learning. Teachers will prepare learning opportunities that review previous standards as well as challenge students to grow their thinking and understanding. Students will have the opportunity to interact with teachers, and sometimes classmates, as well receive educational support by email, phone, or video conferencing such as Google Meets.

The Illinois State Board of Education recommends that any student work completed during this remote learning period only positively impacts student grades. Grades may be assigned, however, student grades or academics standing will not be harmed as a result of Remote Learning.The primary focus during Remote Learning Days will be the continuation of learning and providing feedback to students on assigned learning activities to assist students with reaching mastery of critical standards.

Attendance may be taken for the purpose of identifying students who may need additional assistance or support. Non-attendance will not be penalized. Though these are not typical school days, student participation and completion of assignments is expected. We ask that you communicate that expectation to your child. Your child’s teacher or a school administrator will reach out to see if support is needed if a student is not participating.

div.p: For our high school seniors, we know there is uncertainty over the milestone events for the Class of 2020. The decision to postpone or cancel these events and the impact it has on our students and families weighs heavily on all of us. Please know final decisions have not been made yet on some of these future events and you will be receiving information from the Lisle High School Principal, Mr. Howard, in the coming weeks.

As our students resume remote learning on Tuesday, April 7, we are fortunate to have dedicated teachers working to provide the best educational opportunities possible under these unprecedented circumstances. We would encourage you to visit our Remote Learning page of our website for more information, including an updated FAQ for families.
Thank you for your continued support.

Keith Filipiak
Superintendent

h2.a: Corporate Support Resources - Internet, Utilities, Pharmacy

a.title: Illinois State Board of Education resource page

h5.a: Illinois State Board of Education Resource Page

div.p: Comcast is providing 60 days of free internet service to all qualifying families through their Internet Essentials program. The program provides access for low-income families. In addition to providing a free 60 days to new customers, they are also increasing bandwidth for all Internet Essentials customers. For more info visit https://www.internetessentials.com/ or call 1-855-846-8376 (English) or 1-855-765-6995 (Spanish).

XFinity is opening their wi-fi hotspots to the public, regardless of whether you are an existing XFinity customer or not. They are also eliminating data caps and not disconnecting or imposing late fees on existing customers who cannot pay their bill. https://corporate.comcast.com/covid-19

ATT is suspending broadband data caps. They are also opening their wi-fi hotspots to the public, regardless of whether you are an existing AT&T customer or not. They are not disconnecting or imposing late fees on existing customers who cannot pay their bill. https://about.att.com/pages/COVID-19.html
T-Mobile is giving all of their customers unlimited data and 20 GB mobile hotspot data. https://www.t-mobile.com/news/t-mobile-update-on-covid-19-response

Due to economic circumstances related to the coronavirus and to keep customers connected during this economic and global crisis; Verizon waives late fees for those impacted by COVID-19 https://www.verizon.com/about/news/update-verizon-serve-customers-covid-19

ul.li:
For the next 60 days, we will support our residential and small business customers by:
Not terminating service if they are unable to pay their Sprint bill because of the coronavirus, and
Waiving late fees incurred because of economic circumstances related to the pandemic.
Starting on Tuesday, customers with international long distance calling plans will receive complimentary international calling rates from the U.S. to countries defined by the CDC as Level 3.

div.p: ComEd is taking action to help its customers with payment assistance programs and by imposing a moratorium on service disconnections and waiving new late payment charges through at least May 1, as many businesses and institutions are following guidance from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention by taking temporary measures to shut down or limit operations to control the spread of COVID-19.

ComEd is also taking steps to expand awareness of the programs in place to help customers through temporary or extended financial hardship and will be working with customers on a case-by-case basis to establish payment arrangements and identify energy assistance options. https://www.comed.com/News/Pages/NewsReleases/2020-03-13.aspx

Nicor Gas voluntarily has suspended service disconnections for non-payment, effective immediately for both residential and commercial customers through May 1. https://www.nicorgas.com/company/press-room/nicor-gas-provides-energy-assistance-resources.html

Walgreens is waiving delivery fees for all eligible prescriptions during this evolving situation. https://news.walgreens.com/press-releases/general-news/walgreens-takes-further-action-to-support-customers-during-covid-19-pandemic.htm

CVS Pharmacy will deliver prescribed medications to customers for free to ensure those most vulnerable to the disease don’t have to venture out. Aetna, a CVS company, will also waive early refill limits on 30-day prescriptions for medicines typically needed to address chronic conditions like hypertension and asthma.

h2.a: Social-Emotional Resources for Adults, Teens, & Children

div.p: As our community navigates this COVID-19 pandemic, we have compiled resources on how to support children who are experiencing strong emotions. We have included calming and mindfulness strategies that children can use to cope with their worried feelings. There are also resources to help manage feelings of stress and anxiety that you may be experiencing in these uncertain times.

The Illinois Department of Human Services has launched a support line called Call4Calm that is reachable via text. Individuals who want to speak with a mental health professional can text the word “TALK” or “HABLAR” (for Spanish speakers) to 552-020. That individual will receive a call from a mental health professional employed by a local community health center. People can also text other terms, like “unemployment” or “food” or “shelter” to the same number to receive information on how to navigate and access supports and services. Call4Calm is free, and individuals who use it can remain anonymous.

b.a: How you and your kids can de-stress during Coronavirus

a.title: how to talk to kids and teens about the coronavirus article
a.b: Psychology Today: How to talk to kids and teens about the coronavirus

li.b: Shine: Mental Health resources for COVID-19

b.a: 7 Cups - Online text chat for emotional support and counseling

ul.li: Emotions Anonymous - An international fellowship of people who desire to have a better sense of emotional well-being. EA members have in person and online weekly meetings available in more than 30 countries with 600 active groups worldwide. The EA is nonprofessional and can be a complement to therapy.
Support Group Central - Offers virtual support groups on numerous mental health conditions - free or low-cost. Website also offered in Spanish.

TheTribe Wellness Community - Free, online peer support groups offering members facing mental health challenges and/or difficult family dynamics a safe place to connect. Support groups include Addiction, Anxiety, Depression, HIV/AIDS, LGBT, Marriage/Family, OCD and Teens.
SupportGroups.com - Website featuring 200+ online support groups.

For Like Minds - Online mental health support network that allows for individuals to connect with others who are living with or supporting someone with mental health conditions, substance use disorders, and stressful life events.
18percent - Offers a free, peer-to-peer online support community for those struggling with a wide range of mental health issues.
Psych Central - Offers online mental health resources, quizzes, news, an “Ask the Therapist” function, and online support communities.

li.a: A Comic Explaining Coronavirus for Kids - NPR

b.a: Breathe, Think, Do With Sesame Street

a.title: coping after a disaster kids book

div.p: DuPage County residents and healthcare professionals with concerns about exposure or specific symptoms are encouraged to call the DCHD Communicable Disease and Epidemiology (CDE) program at (630) 221-7553 (8:00 a.m. – 4:30 p.m.) or (630) 682-7400 after hours.
Additionally, for anyone feeling emotional distress or in need of emotional support, the DCHD Crisis Hotline (630) 627-1700 is available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, 365 days a year.

div.h5: Illinois COVID-19 Hotline and Email Address
div.p:
If you have questions about Coronavirus-
Call the Illinois Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19) Hotline 1(800) 889-3931 or,
Send an email to: DPH.SICK@ILLINOIS.GOV
Anytime, 24 hours a day, seven days a week.

div.class: fsDiv fsStyleOneThird fsStyleColumn fsStyleColumn-2 fsStyleColumn-last fsStyleAutoclear

ul.li: Wash hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds.
If soap and water are not available, use hand sanitizer.
Avoid touching eyes, nose, and mouth with unwashed hands.
Discourage food and beverage sharing.
Avoid close contact with people who are sick.
Stay home when you are sick.
Cover cough or sneeze with a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.

li.p: Our custodial staff has increased its efforts to include daily sanitation of light switches, door knobs/push bars, desk and table tops, drinking fountains and other commonly used surfaces.
Hand sanitizer and tissues are available in classrooms and throughout the buildings.

ul.li: Nurses continue to follow protocols for students with fever and respiratory symptoms.

p.meta: At this time, the Illinois State Board of Education has determined the days included in the school closure through March 31, 2020 are considered “Act of God” days and will not need to be made up at the end of the year.

hr.p: At this time we are finalizing options for a contingency learning plan to provide students access to core subject content. More information will be shared shortly.
